fdd:FDD.titleName: MPEG-4, Visual Coding, Simple Scalable Profile

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:fullName: ISO/IEC 14496-2:2004. Information technology -- Coding of audio-visual objects -- Part 2: Visual. Simple Scalable Profile (formal name); MPEG-4, Visual Coding, Simple Scalable Profile (common name)

fdd:description.p: See also MP4_FF_2 and MPEG-4_V. Intended to serve the same applications as the Simple Profile (mobile audio-visual services, low-complexity video for the Internet, and small camera devices that record to disk or memory chips) but adds scalability.
The Simple Scalable Profile permits the use of the following visual object types:

ul.li: Simple: rectangular video, uses intra (I) and predicted (P) video object planes (VOPs, the MPEG-4 term for frames).
Simple Scalable: rectangular video, adds bidirectional (B) video object planes (VOPs), and permits temporal and spatial scalability, which entail the use of layers similar to those in JPEG 2000.

fdd:description.p: The Simple Scalable Profile permits the use of three compression levels which build on Levels 1 and 2 of the Simple Profile.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Scalable video encoding intended to serve the same applications as the MPEG-4 Simple Profile (mobile audio-visual services, low-complexity video for the Internet, and small camera devices that record to disk or memory chips) with added support for temporal and spatial scalability.

fdd:movingImageQF.fdd:clarity: See MP4_FF_2 and MPEG-4_V. Other profiles will produce greater clarity than the Simple Scalable Profile at a given picture size, data rate, and encoding algorithm.

fdd:other.fdd:tag: File type brand (ISO Base Media File Format)

fdd:values.fdd:note: Indicated in file wrapper and relates to "brands" defined in ISO_BMFF. Wrapping MPEG-4_V bitstreams in MP4_FF_1 would occasion the use of mp41; in MP4_FF_2, use mp42. See Part 15 of the standard, pp. 2-9, 13.

fdd:values.fdd:note: Indicators for Simple Scalable Profile, levels 0, 1, and 2 are 00010000, 00010001, 00010010, respectively. From Annex G of ISO/IEC 14496-2:2004, Table G.1
